titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Busied all the morning in writing the Gazette N. 1. for May— We were to have dined at Lord Carysfort’s at Charlottenburg, but Mrs: A— was not well enough to go— Somewhat busied in making preparations for our departure.
2. Letter to my father. (Gaz: 5) enclosed to Mr: King— Mrs: A— quite unwell, and in the evening extremely ill— Read Schiller’s history of the thirty years war— Weather damp and unpleasant.

3. Mr: Kinnaird and Mr: Proby called on me this morning— Wrote a little; and very slowly— Dr: Brown inoculated the child with the small pox— The vaccine matter— In which I have not yet so entire a confidence as in the other; but which from circumstances I am necessitated to prefer.

4. Dined at Lord Carysfort’s, in town; it being the king of England’s birth day. But Lord Carysfort himself was confined with the gout and did not appear. The company consisted of about twenty persons.— At the Casino where Mr: Casamajor and Mr: Proby were balloted.— Evening in the park.

5. Countess Brühl and her daughters, Lady Carysfort, Mr: Casamajor and Mr: Proby, and Dr: Brown’s family dined with us— Mrs: A— continues still infirm and feeble, but attended the company— Count Brühl and Lord Carysfort were both prevented by illness from coming— In the evening I walk’d.

6. Called this forenoon at Schickler’s Compting house— Mrs: A— is this day much better— Apparently better than at any time since her lying-in.— A few Boston Centinels of Feby: and March, came for Mr: Welsh.— Finished second letter upon Gentz’s essay but did not send it.

7. Continued to read in Tillotson’s rule of faith. It is a discussion whether the Scriptures or tradition are the proper rule of Christian faith— A great question between the Catholics and the protestants— Mrs: A— went to Charlottenburg, in the forenoon. I went to see the celebrated monument erected in honour of the Count de la Marche, a natural child of the late king, by Madame Rietz— He died at eight years of age— The figure of the child at full length is lying upon a bed, the sword just dropp’d from his hand. In the wall above is a niche, with the three Destinies, sitting; forms rather larger than human, submitting with reluctance to the decree they find written, to snap the fatal thread— On the long side of the tomb, Time is dragging the child along, to thrust him into the pit, while he struggles, with backward looks to Minerva, who sits, concerned at the loss of so promising a youth. At the two end sides are copies of the antique monumental figures of Sleep and Death— The execution of this work, by Schado, is fine— The form of the child upon the tomb is full of grace. The fatal Sisters are worthy of a Grecian sculptor; the figure of Time appears the least deserving encomium—but the whole is a master-piece— The Latin inscription inter alia says the child already possess’d egregious virtues.— A bastard infant—dead in his ninth year— A superb and costly monument—in a Christian church—and a marble record of his egregious virtues!— The late king was a man of a mild and amiable personal disposition, and an elegant taste in the arts— But his moral feeling! his sense of what is decent and becoming; what was it?

8. Writing the third and last Letter upon Mr: Gentz’s book. In the evening I went to the play, and saw Gustavus Wasa, a tragedy by Kotzebue— This is one of the factious Subjects suited to the spirit of the times; and the author has treated it accordingly— His Christiern is not only the most odious but the most despicable of tyrants—at once the bloodiest of butchers and the basest of cowards— His archbishop of Upsal is his only confidential councillor, equally wicked, with cold blood and firm nerves— His Ahrendt Pehrson, the nobleman with a fine castle, betrays his old friend, and shamefully violates the laws of hospitality— The models of virtue contrasted with these characters, are a Dalecarlian peasant in extremest poverty, and the Burgomaster of Lubeck, a Republican Hans town— Gustavus himself does nothing for his Country, through the whole play— The plot is that of a common Harlequin pantomime; a continual alternation of the hero’s perils and escapes. His heroic atchievements are confined to kneeling and praying, and making one short inflammatory speech to the Dalecarlian peasants— It is one of Kotzebue’s poorest plays.
9. Letter to my brother with N. 2 on Gentz’s book; enclosed to Mr: Pitcairn— Beginning to pack up my last trunk of books. Mrs: Brown called this evening to see Mrs: A—

10. Still reading Schiller’s history of the thirty years war— It is but a collection of fragments; and his impartiality is not very exemplary— But the style is good, and many of the reflections are just and valuable. Wrote a little this morning.

11. Called this morning at Juel’s and bespoke some books. Dined at Dr: Brown’s; and play’d a game of chess with him after dinner. Mr: Proby dined there— Mr: M’Culloch and Sir Simon Taylor came in after dinner. Rode with Mrs: A— in the evening— Received letters & newspapers from my brother, to April 12.

12. Wrote to my brother— Lady Carysfort called in the evening to see Mrs: A— The weather has become very cold— I bathed however in the river— The child quite unwell—probably the consequence of his inoculation.

13. Still cold— Letter to my brother, with N. 3. on Gentz, enclosed to Mr: King. Went in the evening to the play. Saw a play, called A new leaf turned over, by Schröder: very amusing— Herdt uncommonly well— The farce was of Kotzebue—The unhappy kinsmen.— The respectable character of the play, is a clergyman, unhappy, because he has been for thirty years compell’d by poverty to preach what he does not believe. Poor Kotzebue vents his spleen against the German reviewers who have uncovered his nakedness— One of his brightest strokes of Satire upon them is, for publishing their reviews in Latin characters instead of the black letter.

14. Dined with Lord Carysfort, at Charlottenburg— Mrs: A— was unwell, and not able to go.— Return’d to town; and spent the evening at Bellevue— Whist with the Minister Buchholtz, Mr: Sydow, and Mr: Engeström— Took leave of Prince and Princess Ferdinand; and Prince & Princess Radziwill.

15. Mrs: Adams went out and dined at Charlottenburg with Lady Carysfort. I was busied in packing up, for our departure. Went to the play in the evening and saw the conspiracy of Fiesco by Schiller.— A tragedy containing many good and many ridiculous things— He calls it a Republican tragedy— And his object appears to show the government and the conspirators against it in a light equally odious.
16. Continue our preparations for departure— We dined at Dr: Brown’s— Mr: Casamajor and Mr: Proby were there— We took leave of the family in the evening.

17. At half past seven this morning we took our final leave of Berlin, and came in the course of the day seven German miles to Fehrbellin— About a mile before reaching the town we pass’d a small column; with an inscription purporting that Frederic William the Great, came, saw and conquered on the 18th: of June 1675— This was a celebrated battle in the annals of Brandenburg.

18. Mrs: Adams very unwell the whole day— So that she was scarcely able to travel— We came however to Kletzke—a distance of 7 German miles, now enlarged to 8 by the government, which has added the charge of half a mile to each stage— At Kletzke we met Mr Knoblauch, who has been to Copenhagen, and is now returning to Berlin.

19. Mrs: Adams is much better— We came through Perleberg to Lenzen, only five miles; a very easy day’s journey— Lenzen is the last town in the Prussian dominions— We lodge at the same house that we did in going to Berlin

20. Came two very long stages; to Lubtheen and Boizenburg. Eight miles in all— We were two days in going them when we went to Berlin— The sand is excessively deep— We did not reach Boizenburg, till about ten at night— We lodged out of the town, at a very good inn— Mrs: A— excessively fatigued.

21. Travelled seven miles in two stages, and reached Hamburg at seven in the Evening— Mr: Pitcairn sent his servant with a message, being himself too unwell to come out— We lodge at Atkinson’s new Globe Hotel, where he had taken apartments for us— Saw in the evening Captain Ingersoll, of the Ship Catherine.

22. Call’d on Mr: Pitcairn early this morning; he is very unwell— We went with Captain Ingersoll on board his ship, which we found very small indeed— Mrs: Pitcairn call’d on Mrs: A— We dined with them— Mr: Colombi the Spaniard, with another of his countrymen, and Mr: Hazlehurst of Philadelphia were of the company— We did not come home till nearly 9 in the evening.

23. Mr: Mansfield, Captain Clark, Mr: Proud, and another young American called upon me this forenoon. I went on board of Captain Seaward’s ship, bound to Philadelphia— Found it larger, and with better accommodations than Ingersoll’s— Dined again with Mr: Pitcairn, who continues very ill with a sore throat— Play’d chess with him in the evening.— Received a letter from Mr: Engeström.

24. Went again with Mrs: A— on board of Captain Seaward’s ship— But he has too many passengers— Ingersoll came and recommended me the ship America, Captain Wells; going to Philadelphia— I went with him on board the ship, and finding it the most convenient that I have yet met, engaged a passage with him; for an hundred guineas; and to find ourselves in provisions &c— Mrs: Pitcairn came to tea with Mrs: A— and I went and play’d chess with him— Answered Mr: Engeström’s letter.

25. Wrote to the Secretary of State— We dined with Mr: Pitcairn, and in the evening went with his Lady to the french play, where we saw les déguisemens amoureux, a very miserable imitation of a kind of play which they call proverbes— And les Visitandines; pretty well performed— After the play I went again to Pitcairn’s for a game of chess.— Walk’d round the ramparts before dinner—

26. Letter from Mr: Richard at Berlin, with the account of sales of our furniture; and bills of exchange for the money. I went to Mr: Gabe, who agreed to pay the bill by transfer in bank account to Mr: Pitcairn— And to the brothers Beneke and Moller, who pay the money to-morrow morning— Spent the evening with Pitcairn; and his wife with mine— He is better.
27. Wrote to my brother, in answer to his letter of May 7. and the Port-Folio’s to N: 19. Dined with Pitcairn— Mr: Olden a young man from Philadelphia, there— Evening pass’d at chess.
28. Past the forenoon in writing— Walk’d on the ramparts before breakfast— We dined again with Pitcairn; I spent the Evening with him too; and play’d chess.

29. Morning walk on the ramparts which is the most pleasant part of the town— Reading Ancillon’s melanges de morale, politique &c— Garve’s translation of Cicero’s Offices &c— Went in the evening to the play with Mrs: Pitcairn— The plays and performance were both indifferent— Chess with Pitcairn after the play. Mr: Parish called upon me this morning.
30. Called on Mr: Pitcairn in the forenoon; and spend the evening with him at chess. Mrs: P. pass’d it with Mrs: A—
Day. The first part of the month was employed in making our preparations to leave Berlin and return to America— The last ten days at Hamburg, without any regularity.
